textBox.richText: I’ve never used OSX so the joy of getting my hands on a shiny (albeit second hand) Macbook Pro was cut rather short by my inability to accomplish the most basic of tasks. I must admit I was a bit underwhelmed. I was expecting (and rightly so since several colleagues are huge Apple advocates) a more, err, user friendly experience. Is it just me or is it particularly difficult to move and organise Windows (why can you only resize from the bottom right-hand corner)? Anyhow, enough winging, I managed to overcome my OSX prejudices and get on with the matters at hand. I should mention that I did start with a brief(ish) web based proof of concept so I had an idea of what the layout would be and how the code would fit together. I decided to split the front-end (Cocoa objective c stuff) from the back end calculations so I could put these in a separate C++ library. The thinking behind this was that I could knock the library out in a relative small amount of time and it would minimise the amount of Objective C I would need to write. In practice, however, I actually lost some of the useful date/time utilities that Objective C would have given me and ended up having to hand roll some of these in C++, so probably negating any gains I was hoping to make. To be honest Objective C wasn’t the massive headache I thought it would be. Once you get a handle on properties and the strange syntax then you can get going fairly quickly. Getting to grips with the various Cocoa frameworks and Xcode is, however, quite time consuming. You need to read the documentation, run through a few examples and then re-read the docs again. Working with navigation, tabbar and tableview controllers can be a chore so best to find a close example from the Apple developer website and use this as a starting point. I would love to say it has only taken me a week to write the app but it’s taken the best part of 3 months and I haven’t finished. One of the main problems is trying to achieve things too quickly. There is no magic way of speeding up the learning process (well not for me anyway). I found that I would often sit down at around 9:00pm after making the dinner / getting the kids in bed etc. and find myself rushing to achieve something when really I should have spent more time learning and understanding. I managed to wangle a weekend away without the kids and this is, undoubtedly, where I made the most progress. I would recommend to anyone in a similar position to take the time off work (if at all feasible) and spend one or two solid weeks of developing as this is probably the equivalent of a man month or more when split over the occasional hour here or there.
